newsitem.title: UK: BSkyB names JSkyB exec as CEO after Chisholm.
newsitem.headline: BSkyB names JSkyB exec as CEO after Chisholm.

text.p: British Sky Broadcasting Group Plc (BSkyB) said on Tuesday chief executive Sam Chisholm would step down at the end of the year on medical advice.

The satellite television operator, in which Rupert Murdoch's News Corp Ltd has a 40 percent stake, named Mark Booth, chief operating officer of Japan's JSkyB, to replace Chisholm as from January 1, 1998.
BSkyB said Chisholm, who oversaw the company's turnaround to profitability since taking over as CEO in 1990, would remain a director.

"It is no secret that I am an asthma sufferer, and my doctors have advised me that I should not take on the next stage of BSkyB's development ... In the meantime, it is business as usual," Chisholm said in a statement.
Murdoch said he regretted Chisholm's departure.
"Sam Chisholm is unquestionable one of the best executives I have ever worked with ... BSkyB is an amazing company, and Mark Booth will continue the company's success," Murdoch said.
News Corp also has a stake in Japan Sky Broadcasting, a venture with Japan's Softbank Corp, Sony Corp and Fuji Television Network.
